titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller (Nelson A.) Gubernatorial records, Ann C. Whitman, Gubernatorial, Series 35
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller Gubernatorial records, Ann C. Whitman, Gubernatorial, Series 35 FA374

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-06-19 00:19:35 -0400.

revisiondesc.item: Migrated from Re:discovery to the Archivists' Toolkit by Becky Robbins.

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller gubernatorial records, Ann C. Whitman, Gubernatorial, Series 35

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller served as governor of New York from January 1, 1959, to December 18, 1973. He was the first person elected to four consecutive four-year terms as a state governor.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of U.S. copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: There are four subseries in this series, all of which are arranged alphabetically:
Subseries 1: Correspondence, 1967-1970 Subseries 2: Kissinger Reports on World Affairs and Countries, 1967-1969 Subseries 3: Issues and People, 1966-1973 Subseries 4: Campaign 1968

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Ann Cook Whitman (1908-1991) was born in Perry, Ohio. She attended Antioch College, where she enrolled in the school's work-study program. She was sent to the Institute for Child Guidance in New York City. She chose a career as a secretary and left college. Her next job was as a personal secretary to Adele Rosenwald Levy, whose father, Julius Rosenwald, was a founder of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

In the early 1950s, Whitman worked for the Committee for a Free Europe. She was recruited to work for the Eisenhower presidential campaign in 1952, going on to work for Eisenhower as his personal secretary through his eight years in the White House and then for a short time at President Eisenhower's retirement home at Gettysburg.

In 1961, Whitman went to work for George Hinman, a political advisor to Governor Nelson Rockefeller. In 1965 she became Rockefeller's executive assistant. She went on to serve as Rockefeller's chief of staff during the first six months of his Vice Presidential tenure. In June 1975, Whitman returned to New York, assisting Rockefeller until her retirement in 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: NOTE TO RESEARCHERS

This series contains the office files of Ann C. Whitman. They document her official activities in the execution of her duties as a member of Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's staff. The actions, decisions, and exchanges of information or points of view documented here occured in the course of proposing and implementing policies for the Rockefeller administration, political campaigns, and/or Rockefeller's personal activities. However, unless a document is personally signed by Nelson A. Rockefeller, or is referred to in a document personally signed by him, it should not be assumed he saw the document or was aware of its existence or substance. Furthermore, researchers should bear in mind that staff files may contain documents or drafts addressed to Rockefeller that were never shown to him.
SCOPE AND CONTENT

In her role as Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's executive assistant, Ann Whitman maintained a large number of his office files. This series primarily covers the time period surrounding the 1968 Presidential election, when Governor Rockefeller sought the Republican party's presidential nomination. A significant portion of the material deals with the deepening conflict in Vietnam.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Detailed finding aids for each series of this collection are available:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of name and subject files containing correspondence between Governor Rockefeller and staff members and advisors. For example, a folder titled "Nixon-Agnew Campaign," contains information on Governor Rockefeller's role in the 1968 campaign of Richard Nixon. The information in this subseries deals with political and governmental issues and is primarily concerned with the 1968 presidential campaign.

did.unittitle: Kissinger Reports on World Affairs and Countries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains reports organized, drafted, and written by Kissinger or his staff, and submitted to Governor Rockefeller by Henry Kissinger. Kissinger and Rockefeller worked together on projects dating from the time when Kissinger directed the Rockefeller Brothers Fund Special Studies Project. Kissinger was on the faculty of Harvard University when these reports were prepared. Following the 1968 presidential election he began his service to the federal government as a Special Assistant to Richard Nixon.

The majority of the information contained in the reports and workbooks was eventually placed into the "Workbook on Problems in Foreign Policy of the United States," a staff report for the Republican Governor's Association Policy Committee, published in June 1968. There are also meeting notes with background information on foreign dignitaries that Rockefeller was scheduled to meet. There is also a folder of material prepared for Governor Rockefeller in advance of the Presidential Mission to Latin America, which was undertaken at the request of President Nixon in 1969.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a portion of the working files of Governor Rockefeller. New York State issues predominate; however, many files are concerned with national matters, reflecting his pursuit of the Republican presidential nomination in 1968 and his general interest in broader issues. On March 21, 1968, Governor Rockefeller declared he would not be a candidate for President in 1968. On April 30, he reversed himself and redeclared his candidacy for the Republican nomination. He actively campaigned until the Republican Convention. Of note in this subseries are three folders of Governor Rockefeller's handwritten notes from meetings he attended; the notes are undated and the majority do not identify the nature of the meetings.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Two albums of photos, one titled "1973 Spring Republican Governors Conference, New York, New York," the other "1973 National Governors Conference, Lake Tahoe, Nevada" were removed from this series and placed with the Nelson A. Rockefeller Photograph Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains material pertaining to Governor Rockefeller's run for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1968. The subseries is comprised primarily of lists of individuals who assisted on the campaign and were to receive thank you notes from Governor Rockefeller. At the conclusion of the subseries is an alphabetical run of state files. These files contain press releases announcing the naming of state chairs of Rockefeller for President committees in 39 states and the District of Columbia. File titles containing the name of a city and a date, indicate a "trip briefing book" outlining scheduled appearances by Governor Rockefeller in that state. File folders for the remaining 11 states were empty and were discarded during processing.
